Yes, I have 20 hours in this game. But first, some background.  Like with Final Fantasy XIII and Remember Me, I avoided this game because people complained about it when it came out despite me being hyped for it. I bought it when it was on sale for a dollar and regret not buying it day-of.  I can see where people can find significant flaws, especially playing now just before the new game comes out, but there's so much good in this game that I think it's okay to overlook. The story's a little undercooked, Merc annoys the hell out of me (the white guy who's talking in your ear for 90% of the game), and for such an important character, you see Faith's sister three times and she does nothing significant. The borderless cartoon animation comic-wannabe cutscenes between levels are tragic and make my heart hurt. The biggest complaint I've seen is also slightly true: yes, some jumps and parkour tricks can be difficult to pull off because of finicky controls and poor item interaction (like not being in the correct centimeter length from a pipe so you fall to your death despite staring right at the bloody thing).  But, honestly, the only parts of the game I got truly and genuinely frustrated at were the fights (particularly one boss fight with a ninja person *spoiler spoiler*). Thank god Catalyst ditched the guns because wow, I didn't get this game to play a shooter.  Despite all of this, which I guess some is enough to ruin this game for people, I cannot recommend this game enough. It is quite possibly one of my favorite games of all time, and I play a lot of games. I spent $200 on Catalyst and got the prequel graphic novel. I own the soundtrack to the first game and will probably get the next. I seriously love this game. So what's good?  It's art, pure and simple. And there's nothing else like it. Maybe some indie stuff popped up in hopes of scratching that virtual parkour itch, but nothing really compares to this full game of jumps and swings. It's like making Assassin's Creed first person and giving you complete control of every wall dash, every jump, every lunge, all those little tricky grabs and spins, and turning travel into the puzzle rather than combat or hacking minigames. Every tiny detail is carefully created and placed to challenge you and force you to think creatively, using the tools you learn in the tutorial on increasingly difficult puzzles. Even the fights can sometimes be enjoyable when you treat it as a marathon instead of an fps shooting gallery.  The game is gorgeous, even for today's standards (though Faith's model is a little choppy). The color contrast and choice in neon vibrance and bright white have been lauded for years now. And it always stands our, no matter how many times you play the game. In a world of greys and browns, this game is quite the visual gem and that can't be understated. Traveling over skyscrapers really shows all these contrasts, then busting into office buildings and cunstruction sites, subways and malls, put those big blues, oranges, and greens right in your face.  I'm a huge cyberpunk fan and there's not a lot of it. People want to think it died in the '80s, but I say ♥♥♥♥ that. Even if we don't have AIs or cyberspace, this is cyberpunk. A small group of rebels try to circumnavigate the system that the ruling totalitatarian government has created in this near-future dystopia. It's guilded, with high-rises and men in swanky suits, but crime and death in the cracks. This point's more about my personal interests, but anything cyberpunk is a win in my book.  The music perfectly frames everything going on. It's fast, it's calm, and it's creepy. People complain about 'Still Alive' but I'm one of the nerds who loves that ♥♥♥♥ing song. When i heard the composer for the main soundtrack was coming back, I immediately got the collector's for Catalyst. He's good. It's soft, kinda futuristic (as we'd like to imagine it) and is the perfect audial counterpart to the colorful visuals.  Then there's time trials and doing speedruns of actual levels from the game, which is always fun. There's hackers on the pc, so don't bother trying to be number one on the leaderboards, but it can be very fun to push yourself to beat your own best times. Some of the most fun I had in this game was discovering new and faster ways of completing levels, like trick jumps I missed on my initial run or near-glitches that let you skip whle sections. I suppose these types of things exist in all sorts of games, but it truly feels different in a game with the parkour gameplay like this. I also thought the voice-acting was well done, particularly on faith and Jacknife, even Merc (despite me loathing his voice).  I am a very big fan of this game, now franchise, and will likely love it forever. No, it's not perfect. If it was, would we need a sequel? But it's unique, fun, and stays in your brain. Granted, the folks around here bashing on it aren't likely to think about it again, but how are you to know you won't love it until you try it?  One scene will always stick with me. Faith's sister's first appearance is in a cutscene, and not one with that horrible cartoon animation, but a realtime in-game cutscene in first person. There aren't a lot of these (in fact, off the top of my head, I can only remember two). This one is a good length, the vast city is visible in the background, you don't have control over Faith's actions, and it's emotional. It sets up the plot for the game (which isn't dreadful, they just could've done al ot more with it) and the relationship between Faith and her sister. Faith's personality is on full display here, her drive to run and escape problems rather than face them, and we never see her face. Many fps games don't have cutscenes from first person where the first-person character actually does stuff that the player doesn't do. But it's not awkward, it doesn't feel weird, even when the two sisters embrace and you see Kate's head go over Faith's shoulder. It's fluid and makes me wish there were more of these throughout the game. Even outside of the parkour, the music, and the visuals, this style of cutscene will always stick with me.  TLDR- I love it, you might, there's problems, what game doesn't? You won't know if you're a hater or a lover until you try it. There's running, jumping, music, some iffy storytelling, and an overall unique experience. I've also heard it's good with VR. Give it a shot, it may just be your next obsession.

Mirror's Edge was developed by DICE and released in 2010. Unlike other DICE games, Mirror's Edge wasn't using the Frostbite engine, instead they went with Unreal Engine 3.  There is no game like it. The parkour is simply amazing here. There is no run button in this game - instead your character simply builds up speed as she runs. To complete an obstacle, you have to do it all in an instant, without stopping. It's not really about planning or puzzles, but more about instinct. You really have to give it to the level design in this game. Without right level design none of it would really feel right. All of that really make it feel very natural and epic. DICE really managed to combine cinematic feel (and i don't mean 30 fps) and gameplay together. I wouldn't mind for a open world though.  There is also a bit of FPS in this game. You can never hold on to a gun or reload it. You have to attack the enemy to get the gun, but it's easier said than done though. The game wants you to be tactical, even if you attack an enemy that only had a pistol, he will still gun you down if you just run out in the open to him like that. You have to use cover, pick the ones that are separated from the rest etc.  The gameplay component of the game, whether it's parkour or shootouts, is simply amazing.  The game also has nice use of aesthetics. They use primary colors mixed with white for the most part. It's so simplistic, yet so gorgeous. Musical department wasn't lacking either. Main theme by Lisa Miskovsky is superb.  Unfortunately this game suffers from one big problem - the length. It will take you about 4 hrs to complete it. I guess EA thought of it as an experiment project?  Additionally, there are also those terrible cutscenes in between the levels. Clearly shows the limited budget EA has given.  Usually i dismiss these 4 hrs long games. Most of them offer no originality and are overpriced. But due to unique nature of Mirror's Edge i will have to recommend it. There is really no game like it.

It's a about 6 hours long, a standard for the time and I feel like it's neither too short nor too long.  I would recommend getting this, especially if you're a fan of parkour and well coded gameplay mechanics.

Mirror's Edge is a phenomenal action platformer. The feeling of satisfaction you get when you land the perfect jump, disarm a cop, or slide kick a dude in the nuts is just tops. The story itself is fairly short, but the replay value seems to be pretty good. There's lots of stuff for you to find around the levels, and beyond that there's time trials and races with leaderboards, if you really want to see how fast you can blow through a level. The music and art are downright breathtaking at times, there was more than one moment where I had to stop running and just look out at the cityscape.   Overall I loved this game, really glad I picked it up finally when it was on sale. The first few times I fell I winced and audibly gasped, it really sucks you in. The few hours it took to get through the story were incredibly exhilarating and visually stunning. Even the combat animations are just so incredibly smooth, you go from running along the side of a wall to twisting a dudes arm around and snatching his gun in a few seemingly effortless motions (if you get your timing right).   Only played through once, on normal difficulty, and I found it pleasantly challenging to downright punishing at times. Some of the sparring with enemy NPCs was ridiculous, but after a few failed attempts I felt like a total badass taking them down.    Highly recommend this game. Visually it's held up over the years, and mechanically it's one of the most thrilling games I've played. Parkour platforming and combat come together like peanut butter and chocolate in Mirror's Edge.

7 out of 10. I'm giving it a thumbs-up because the free-running gameplay is an interesting mechanic, but the game has enough faults that I really only recommend it when you can find it on sale.  All in all not a very good game, even though it seems to have a pretty rabid fan base. To be fair, the graphics are very good, especially considering it's a few years old, and the developers had some innovative ideas for how to play the game. Unfortunately actually playing the game just wasn't as fun as it should have been. Mostly the game suffers from pretty bad controls coupled with unforgiving gameplay mechanics, which results in having to replay sections over and over again. Most jumps and grabs have to be precisely timed and the distance precisely judged, but many times the button presses didn't register quickly enough, and it's in general pretty difficult to judge distances, so I found myself dying dozens of times when I missed jumps by no more than an inch or two - that got frustrating really fast. The control issue also raised its ugly head in the wholly mediocre combat. Many, many times the right-mouse button counterattack failed, which got me killed more times than I could count. I eventually grew to hate the combat so much that I just pounded on the first guard I saw, took his gun, then shot everyone else just to get it over with.  The other huge frustration with the game was the fact that for such a completely linear game it was often nearly impossible to figure out where to go. There was supposed to be a hint system that highlighted your path in red, but sometimes it showed up off in the distance, sometimes not until you were right on top of the path, and sometimes not at all - I wandered around a lot because of that. Even worse was the level where the devs decided to paint everything in the building red; I don't know why, I guess maybe they just thought it was funny to frustrate us even further.  To make matters even worse (or perhaps better, as things turned out) - beyond the spotty controls, oft-failing hint system, unforgiving mechanics and mediocre combat, the game took me all of 5 hours and change to complete. I'm not necessarily opposed to short games, as long as the story is engaging and gameplay is fun - The Darkness II is a perfect example. But this game was neither engaging nor more than moderately fun, and was far too short for the money they normally charge. Luckily I got this as part of the EA Humble Bundle, so I really didn't shell anything out for it. If you can pick it up really cheap then it's fine to waste time on for a few hours, but anything more than a few bucks is probably a waste of your money.

Mirror's Edge is a first person running game developed by DICE. You play as Faith, a free runner. The story is set in a modern utopian society with a totalitarian government. Invasive surveillance is a part of life in this city and runners help exchange information between parties without getting caught.  Gameplay is the most admirable aspect, its not perfect but its very innovative and first of its kind. I was skeptical of how the game is going on handle. I am glad that DICE persisted with the first person perspective because Mirror's Edge is very unique.  Graphics are good enough, some of the views from the tall buildings are beautiful and vertigo inducing. During the frantic chase sequences when there is a real rush to escape, vision tends to get a little blurry by the edges when leapt over rooftops and I could feel my stomach lurch forward at times. Playing this on my 24 inch monitor at 1920x1200 at highest settings with PhysX enabled is real treat.   On the flip side, Mirror's Edge can be frustrating in spite of DICE getting all the hard parts right. They made a game that handles free running extremely well. I never found the camera to be a problem and the controls on the PC are great. I loved the the chase sequences and getting the stunts right is not very difficult. The is hurt mainly by some intentional bad design choices - the scourge of all games. Weapons are extremely weak, it reminded me of Tomb Raider Legend and not in a good way - those of you who played it would know the reference, and melee combat is frustrating and unsatisfying. This only serves to break the momentum needlessly and seemed like an after thought. DICE have developed Battlefield games, so its not as if they are inexperienced in first person shooters, yet the gunplay in Mirror's Edge is very inadequate. I would recommend playing the game on Easy setting to avoid the frustration of combat.  Also, the game is quite short. On Easy I finished the game in about 6 hours. For a free running game to be truly effective, it must have the feel of an open city where the gameplay is not restrictive. I can understand that at times this might be necessary, but throughout the game, you will be in a huge city, which you cannot explore and the path is very linear - just like an old platformer.    + Visuals + Brilliant soundtrack + Decent story telling + Some segments are truly breathtaking + Tight controls  - Very weak combat - Crappy 2D cut scenes - Short

A year or so ago, Mirror’s Edge used to rank highly with me, being one of my favorite games all time, up there with the best of ‘em like Portal and Fallout. While it is still a rather fun and enjoyable experience, coming back to playing on PC, issues started to surface.  Before we get to that, I just want to toss a bit of praise toward the art design behind the game, with high contrast colors and sharp shadows. The Frostbite engine hasn’t age a day, making Mirrors Edge one of the best looking game out there, pleasantly blending a bright, anime-ish style and realistic models and lighting. You will often finding yourself looking around at the sprawling city around you, with light bending over windows, smoke stacks wafting through the air, and the city bustling beneath you.  Besides that, the games primary mechanic, first person platforming or parkour, manages to give you sense of speed and fluidity. When it’s working correctly. You will in frustrating frequency that a path that you have taken is a dead end or not traversable. Forcing you to break game flow for a path that you can take, which you would've never known otherwise. Either that or dying because of shoddy collision detection will have you plummeting to your death more than once. Regardless, if everything works in your favor, good times are to be had, providing a real sense of achievement when you pull off a course nearly flawlessly.  Where I wished Mirror’s Edge would have bared its teeth a bit more with its story, becomes rather forgettable and generic. What works for the story are the cartoon animated cutscenes that tell it, all being a nice little treat visually between levels. The animations are fluid and organic, forms flexing and relaxing in a realistic manner, all tied in with its anime influenced art style. I found myself racing through courses to get to the next animation.  Another thing that works for the game’s detriment in the gameplay department, is the combat system. While it has a fast and simple melee system which is quite good, disarming opposition of their firearms and using them is another story. You will occasionally find yourself getting slapped with the butt of a gun due to, once again, shoddy collision detection. Especially in particular sections where you NEED to get a gun to progress. It’s ♥♥♥♥ing infuriating and hurts the entire game.  Other than what was covered, there’s a few nitpicky things like a minor lack of level variety late game, level padding, and a bit of hyper accurate enemies in some instances. These issues don’t occur often, but enough to annoy if they arise.  With the samey, generic military shooter released year after year, Mirrors Edge was a refreshing take on a wholly new concept that accomplishes it with mixed results. While the art design is stellar, gameplay fun and animations interesting, the ever present shadow of bipolar collision detection, generic story, and pissy combat takes a huge toll on the game’s enjoyability. Mirror’s Edge is fun, when everything is working right.   Verdict : 6.75 -  Enjoyable

Mirror's Edge is just like it's heroine. It attempts to hurdle some pretty significant obstacles, however, unlike Faith, Mirror's Edge doesn't always succeed.  The story is somewhat straightforward, but it's interesting enough to keep you engaged. However, a cliff-hanger ending and an only just announced sequel make for a slightly unfinished feel. However, more intriguingly, what did catch my interest was the way the story played out between missions; through stylishly animated cut-scenes, as well as scenes within the game engine itself, which also look attractive. While, as I am an animator myself, these cut-scenes are a pleasant addition, they feature a completely different art style. Both types look good, but the disparity is a little odd.  Mirror's Edge is a first person perspective 'free-runner' platformer whereby you take the role of Faith, making countless sequences of jumps, grabs and slides to reach the end of a partially open world stage. As a 'Runner', it's all about speed and momentum, with keeping your moves streamlined, flawless and silky smooth a top priority if you are to finish a stage in a set time, or outrun a team of enemies. This is an infinitely satisfying and thrilling game play formula that rarely misses a mark, inflicting gleeful vertigo in the process. To back this up, the controls are as tight as you could want, with sharp turns and tight slides feeling so, so right. On the PC, the game's graphics are phenomenal, the clean and crisp visual style perfectly enhancing the atmosphere of the futuristic, post-reform utopian city, and cleverly immunising the game's visuals to ageing textures. PC only PhysX capabilities only add to this, with rippling flags and shattering windows adding an increased sense of surrealism. Most of the time, you'll want to avoid tangling with cops and SWAT teams, instead using your agility to out manoeuvre them, but now and again you'll need to fight your way out. Hand to hand combat is generally the best method, with jump kicks and slides being the most efficient and elegant, however punches and kicks feel weighty and satisfying, but with no combo system or progression this feels somewhat paper thin.  The second halve to combat is found when hijacking a cop's gun, however, despite what you might expect, these weapons are in fact less effective than using your fists, especially seeing as how you cannot reload them. These guns are difficult to control, possess no sights or method of active aiming and are generic as hell. I don't usually feel this way, but the game could have been far better off if they were left out entirely and replaced with a better hand to hand combat system. Mirror's Edge has a way of bringing the pace to a halt. Unfortunately, for a game that relies on so much forward momentum, Mirror's Edge has a way of bringing the pace to a halt. It has a tendency to trip over its own feet, keeping you slipping and sliding blissfully along, only to have a intricate but tedious jumping puzzle or hazy objective put the brakes on. These aren't bad, but they're not particularly engaging, either; you're likelier to feel relieved rather than fulfilled when you complete one. In *all*, not some of these cases, you're torn from the experience and reminded that this is, after all, just a game.  Mirror's Edge is many things, and it stumbles often for a game that holds velocity in such high regard. But even with all of its frustrations, it makes some impressive leaps; a unique and adventurous game that makes some brave moves that pay of immensely. Having set a solid foundation, we can expect an impressive improvement in it's upcoming sequel. The first game however, as GameSpot might say... 'it just doesn't nail the landing'.  + Amazing concept and seamless, exhilarating game play design + Clean and crisp, visually pleasing visual style  - Flawed combat system - Lackluster and flow interrupting platforming sections  7.5/10 ~ Good  EpicSouls (Sam)

Do you remember the good days of EA? When the old CEO was out and John Riccitiello was saying all sorts of wonderful things? How we rejoiced that the exploitation of our favourite franchises would end and new IPs would spring from the waters of EA and bring gaming back. Yeah 2008 was a pretty idealistic year. Unfortunately such a magical thing never came to fruition, but we did get one new IP out the door before the name ♥♥♥♥♥♥ began. Mirror's Edge was a first person platformer, for lack of a better word, developed by DICE and released on the 360, PS3 and PC.   Mirror's Edge takes place in a near future city in which it is implied that Big Brother takes a larger role than most feel comfortable admitting. The stark white buildings, bright bloom and overall sterile feel to the buildings you travel on and through do wonders to build this idealistic looking city that is perhaps a little too clean. While the setting is beautiful and immersing, the sheer brightness will mess with more than a few players' eyes.  You play as Faith, a member of a group of package runners that deliver sensitive information and items across the city, usually by way of parkour over the city's rooftops. Her character design is one that should be examined and emulated by current developers. DICE managed to create a character that could be fit and capable and even attractive without the hyper-sexuality that seems to plague the industry. It's a shame we don't get to learn more about her, the game tries to characterize her but ultimately falls flat with a mix of lacking clarity and a subpar execution of the plot.  The game starts off with a light tutorial to get you acquainted with the controls. Your basic movements are jumping, ducking/sliding, strikes and counters. However, context sensitive combos related to walls and objects can result in much more efficient and beautiful parkour moves such as wall running and spin jumps. The controls feel tight but the inability to really see where you're running without looking down can really hinder the timing of the jumps. This is a particularly frustrating fault due to the game's need for absolute precision during some of the levels and you will find yourself repeating some sections more than enough times. Faith's counter attacks against police and security can be used to obtain firearms, which are useful in a pinch but should not be relied upon. There is also an achievement for playing the game without killing a single person, so it is possible to play the game without weapons.   Once the tutorial is completed, the plot is set up, Faith's sister is framed for a murder she didn't commit and Faith does her best to unravel the conspiracy around this assassination and the reason that Faith's sister was targeted. While the plot has the potential to expand and explore the setting of the game, ultimately we're only given flashes of the world and are left wanting; made even more aggravating by a cliff hanger ending.  As far as technical issues go, the game is fairly clean. While the 360 version didn't suffer from any drops, I found a few moments when the PC version slowed down and the frame rate stuttered for what appeared to be no more than some glass shattering.  All in all Mirror's Edge was an experiment. Experiments are rarely flawless but often show promise and that is exactly what Mirror's Edge is; promise and potential a touching lacking in polish. However it's still an excellent experience.

This is one of my favorite games of all time. It is a very unique experience and when you get the flow it's amazing. Some people have complained about the combat systems, but to me it's actually better that the combat is difficult and clunky as compared to a real first-person shooter. This is a running game and the protagonist is not Rambo -- so the combat reflects that fact. You can pass basically any mission without needing to kill people, and it just emphasizes the importance of becoming good at running and dodging.  The level in the glass-walled skyscraper where you have to parkour your way up is my favorite level. It's a beautiful level and has fun jumping/climbing challenges.  Be forewarned that you will likely not pass each level on the first try, so there is a lot of re-doing levels as you learn where to run and when to run. This pure gameplay focus is similar to a platformer like Mario Bros., and is NOT like a modern shooter game. The story is also throwaway and didn't add much for me. With the right mentality and approach I was not frustrated by this fact as the game is not super long. I enjoy running the levels enough and trying new approaches to the same problem that the need to re-run levels didn't bother me. After a lot of thought, this still remains my favourite game. The feeling of running through buildings and jumping over rooftops is almost magical and has not been matched by any other game for me. The lighting, appearance of the levels and music is fantastic and increadably atmospheric, giving the feeling of true freedom of leaping across the dystopian City of Glass. Despite, its relative age now, the game still looks great and, partly due to its age, it runs incredably well and smoothly, even on older hardware.  However, the game is by no means perfect. The story and characters are lackluster at best and I didn't really feel any interest or excitment in finding out more - I only wanted to continue for the gameplay, not because of a drive to progress the story or save the characters in danger. The gameplay is also flawed to an extent. For a game about running freely over rooftops, it would make sense to make the game open world but instead the game is made of linear levels. Fortunately, in most cases, there are many ways to progress through the levels, allowing for better replayability as you try to find the optimum routes. The game could be better if these factors were improved, but they did not greatly negatively affect my experience.  The main problem with this game which does cause an issue, however, is its combat system. Firstly, in my opinion, I don't think the game needed offensive combat mechanics since the protagonist, Faith, is a Runner. It would make much more thematic sense for her to just dodge and run past attackers rather than stop and try to fight them. This is a strategy that can be employed most of the time but there are three times in the game where it forces you to fight. The first two sections can be somewhat avoided or minimised by following better routes but there is no way to get past the third section. These completely break up the enjoyment and faced paced action of the rest of the game as you are forced to stop and deal with enemies. The combat system itself is very poor so these sections are by far the worst part of the game. Disarming enemies for a not-lethal takedown (the combat method that seems to fit Faith's character best) is very hard, especially at first, as the trigger is slightly after when you'd expect. After my 8 or so playthroughs of the game, I am still not consistant at disarming enemies who kill you very quickly if you mess up, making me often have to try 10 or more times to get past the combat sections. The gunplay is mediocre and very simple, leading to combat sections feeling like they were added later to the game and didn't have enough development time.  Despite all of these flaws however, the increadble unique feeling that this game offers is unmatched by anything else and it makes me feel excited and in awe every time that I play this game even though I already know the best routes to follow and every level inside out. No other game has or continues to make me feel as thrilled every time I play it. I can't fully describe why I love it; it's just a very special and magical game to me.  Mirror's Edge goes on sale a lot and I've seen the price of this game go very low so if you have a spare few dollars, try it and see for yourself what an amazing experience running freely through the rooftops is.

Mirror's Edge is unique. From its art style to its gameplay, few games can claim to do what it does. It is firsit person platforming from the makers of the Battlefield series. While that series may have its detractors, Mirror's Edge shows that sometimes even the companies that do the big annualized releases have a few tricks up their sleeves.  In the future, the government controls everything. You're Faith, a runner who dashes along rooftops with all the agility of an urban Spider-Man for the underground. While the story is taken from a number of places, the execution makes it stand out. This is one of the best examples of first person platforming in the past decade. The systems aren't as tight as I wish they could be, and problems abound where you question why you missed a jump here or there. But when everything fits and the runs go perfectly, Mirror's Edge delivers an experience few games can claim to match.

Mirror's Edge got some pretty mixed reviews when it came out. Some people liked it, some didn't. The most common complaint I hear from people is that they think the controls suck and it's an example of why platforming shouldn't be done in first-person. I disagree. I played through this game several times, and I earned almost all of the speed-run achievements on 360. Even completely out of practice I can beat this game in about two hours. I love the controls, and I think it's a perfect example of how to do first-person platforming right. It's just one of those games where the controls either click for someone or they don't.  As far as the rest of the package goes, I admit that it leaves something to be desired. The story isn't great, and while it is definitely possible to avoid shooting anyone in this game, there are a couple parts where shooting makes it SO much easier. It shouldn't be that way. It should ALWAYS be easier to avoid conflict. That being said, the other main complaint I hear is that the combat sucks and you can't avoid it. This is also a bit of a misconception if you ask me. Besides those couple parts I mentioned, it is actually easier to learn how to avoid the fight most of the time, but, well, it controls like a first-person shooter and killing folks is how people are used to progressing in a game like this. If you're fighting dudes, you're probably doing it wrong.  Besides that though, it is a fantastic game. I love the look of it, and the abstract-art-esque DLC is absolutely gorgeous.

Stunning visuals considering how old it is, plays like a charm once you get the hang of it too. Nice to have a first-person that actively discourages engaging in gunplay too, that's really not the point of this game, although gun mechanics work fine too. Would recommend (even though I got it on sale at 75% off) getting it even though the sale's just ended, or maybe wait for the next one.  Seriously awesome.

Oh, and did I mention I absolutely love the soundtrack? Still Alive is such an amazing piece to roll credits on. I get chills everytime...  ME is elegant. ME is beautiful. ME is art.

This is one of those 'good but flawed' games that pretentious ♥♥♥♥s like me keep going on about. Mirror's Edge was one of the first games to really experiment with first-person parkour, meaning this is the grandmother of titles like Dying Light.  This game has some good points, and some bad ones.  Good point #1: Gameplay. Although this was kind of an experiment in first-person parkour, the devs really pulled it off. The movement feels satisfying, the controls have great feedback, and the levels have a great sense of flow. It's damn pleasing to experience, as you jump across gaps, clamber over fences and run across walls.  Bad point #1: Combat. A game like this could have some interesting opportunities to use the environment as a weapon, but instead every encounter reverts to poorly implemented first-person shooting. The guns are as satisfying as a wet slap to the face, there's no way to tell how much health you actually have, and the fighting only gets in the way of the freerunning. Thankfully you can often ignore enemies (or run right past them) but the parts where you are required to pick up a gun are terrible.  Good point #2: Nice aesthetic. The artists deserve a pat on the back, because the game looks beautiful, despite its age. Most of this is done through use of colour, and looking out across the entire city is simply breathtaking.  Bad point #2: Story. The plot of Mirror's Edge is generic and forgettable. It's a bog-standard conspiracy story, which never explains why the villains are after you, and which has plot twists that are both completely predictable  and  nonsensical. Eventually I gave up on trying to follow what was going on, and instead tried to ignore the various info-dumps.  Good point #3: Level design. A parkour game without good level design is a bad game, but this game has great level design. The positioning of walls, fences and obstacles is intuitive, with a real cohesive feel. The use of colour also helps to draw the player's eyes towards certain points, and the methods of getting from A to B are logical and enjoyable.  Is this a game worth playing? Yes. Is it a perfect game? No. Will you enjoy it if you play it? Probably.  This is a game that I think really needs a sequel (and we'll be getting one soon), because there is actually some real gold in here, and it would be worth going in to try and make it shinier. A short and sweet experience that was a cocktail of fast-paced parkour puzzles, frustrating combat sequences, and strangely enjoyable 2D animated cutscenes. First-person parkour across an urbanscape feels unique and is relatively simple on the surface, but its complexity comes from performing them in rapid thinking as you dodge pursuit and 'go with the flow.' You keep moving. You don't want to stop. You can't stop. If you stop in a pursuit, you're good as dead.  That kinda brings me to its weak points; the game has unavoidable combat encounters where you have to defeat your pursuers (by disarming/beating them down or shooting them, there's no gameplay/story consequence for killing enemies) rather than going with the adrenaline of dodging bullets like a twitchy monkey. It slogged down that pacing, and the gunplay is intentionally sluggish. It feels like the weakest areas of the game. And the same for the hidden runner bags (collectibles that unlock concept art), which feel like they took away from the momentum. But if you don't have painful compulsions to look for them, then it'll be less a bother.

Just finished this game's story mode. Got it on sale for £2. All things considered, it felt like a bargain.  I loved the aesthetics and when you knew where you were going whilst freerunning it felt really energetic and exciting. Sometimes though, when you tried to jump to a ledge that you could easily make, you'd just plummet to your death (those situations are a mix of it being your fault even if you don't want to admit it and the parkour mechanics falling short). Sometimes it was hard to find where you're supposed to go next as well. This isn't so bad if you're in an area with no enemies and can actually be kind of fun, but you'll end up in really fast-paced situations not knowing where to go, so you have to slow right down which kind of kills the adrenaline rush you get from lightning fast parkour.  I found the story to be a bit lackluster as well. It sounds good on paper, where it's implied that the city the game takes place in is basically NSAland, but the story within the world of Mirror's Edge that focuses on Faith and those she encounters wasn't very engaging. I didn't feel any real connection to any of the characters. I won't describe what happens because nobody likes spoilers, but there are twists and events that happen that you can call very early on.  Also you'll end up in situations where you have to do the exact opposite of what the game tells you to do, which is to avoid combat with large groups of enemies. Occasionally you'll have absolutely no choice but to use the horrible gun mechanics to kill literally everyone before you can move on.  Still, I don't want to sound like I'm too harsh on it. It was an experimental IP that came out almost 8 years ago which succeeded in some areas and less so in others. Overall it's a fun game when the mechanics work properly with attractive level design and an addictive soundtrack (the main menu music is beautifully done) but I would've been disappointed if I paid the full retail price for it.

In a word: Janky.  Mirror's Edge is a game around parkour and flow. It however doesn't flow; not easily.  In story mode, there is very little flow. The levels are often broken up between puzzle-like climbing sections, where the aim is to get from A to B using the available structures, to arcadish shooter segments, running from A to B whilst being fired upon.  In both you are often funneled down a predetermined path. You must jump from here to here to progress. You must pass these dudes to progress. And very little of this lends itself to speed or flow.  To solve the puzzle you must stop and examine the environment, and to pass the shooters you must either stop and dispatch them with your own gun, or try to run straight at or through them as they fire at you (which doesn't work most of the time).  The best bits of the game are between these two segments, where you have space to move. Or when you are simply chased. But these are fleeting, and often the physics of the game conspire to ruin these too.  For instance, run at a wall straight ahead and you will attempt to climb it. Run at it at an angle and you will wall run across it. You can jump onto an object, or automatically vault it plummeting to your doom. Leap at a guys head and knock him to the ground, or stand on them instead. Or the most frustrating grab a ledge, or simply not and fall. Some of these dichomotomies rarely trouble you, aside in small spaces where the difference between the two actions becomes hard to maintain. But some are confused so often that it just leads to repeated attempts and failures. Of course maybe I'm simply bad at the game.  There's a narrative too, such as it is. It is very much a narrative of convenience. Things happen because they need to involve the main character, rather than occuring out of any sort of narrative cause. Take the premise. You are a runner in a city because the guvment is cracking down on crime. And so the crime lords need stuff transported outside of the city's transport system I think. These packages you're meant to be delivering? You never deliver any throughout the game. You never work. You are the worst courier the city has seen. But the crime lords are never seen either so I guess they can't be too mad. Similarly the police have not cracked down on you because of fear of reprisal. Until they do, in the first chapter.  There is race mode, which involves chasing down your own time and that of your friend's ghosts. You could probably try to beat the leader's too, if they weren't cheats with single second runs. Still, this feels like a missed opportunity, as a true race mode, competing head to head parkouring around the city, sounds like great fun (and I think is the premise for Speed Runner, which I'm yet to play).  All in all, this game has a good premise with poor, even sloppy, execution. Which is a huge shame. A sequel is coming out soon though, so perhaps this will improve in the areas above. In any case, either wait for the sequel to come out, or buy this in a sale if you're curious.  Wouldn't recommend. Maybe play like Sonic Adventure 2, or Tony Hawk Pro Skater 2 or 3. It's not parkour, but the freedom of movement and the straight ignoring of physics to allow the flow to continue are there. And the flow is all that matters.

Pros: - The game seems appealing in the trailer, and is somewhat fun to play. - Gives you the feeling of playing Portal (without the portal gun, unfortunately) and Tomb Raider.  Cons: - Jumping around is nowhere as smooth as in Tomb Raider. You end up missing poles and vaults all the time and plummeting to your death. - Potential instant death points are everywhere and check points are relatively rare (or rarer than they should be). Every 5 minutes you come to a spot where you die again and again and the check point is about 1 minute prior to that so you end up frustratingly repeating that 1 minute and dying at that same spot until you are lucky enough to get past the spot. - Cops shoot at you and in many instances there is very little or no way to get rid of them. - You're not supposed to fight back the enemy, Either kill-one-of-them-and-escape or steer-clear-of-all-the-enemies-and-escape. Encountering two or more enemies almost certainly results in death. - The game takes you through 10 minutes of tutorials and never reminds you of the buttons to push in the real game anymore (well except for E for interactions, which is not mentioned in the tutorials). - There are 'packs' to collect but they don't seem to be of any use (for achievements perhaps?) And with the cops constantly shooting you everywhere you go, you don't really have the time or focus to find those seemingly decorative 'packs'.  If you have time, patience and the determination to finish a game before watching the cutscenes/finding out the ending, and Mirror's Edge is on sale, MAYBE buy it. Otherwise, you'd better off giving it a pass.

I don't often have the inspiration to write reviews or comments about games, but in this case I kind felt I had to. This game was on my wishlist for a long time and I loved the demo on the Xbox 360; but the word 'clunky' describes Mirror's Edge all too well.  The screenshots and trailers paint a beautiful picture of freerunning across glorious, colourful rooftops with a seamless flow of wall-running, vaulting and ducking leading to extremely satisfying gameplay... But to be quite honest with you, you're going to be spending 60% of your time inside a claustrophobic building with little to no idea on how to progress. Runner vision shows you where your *end* goal should be, but often the frustration of having no clue how to *get* there by far outweighs the satisfaction one receives from actual free-running. When I bought the game I was hoping to be spending most of my time exploring the open-air environment - not stood at the end of a platform, scratching my head on where on earth to go next. Despite the 'next obstacle' often being highlighted in red, I found these areas simply not 'intuitive' enough for me to follow the supposed 'flow' of the game.  As much as the endless swarms of cops is annoying at times, it is rewarding to outmaneuver them through well-timed counters or simple evasion. As stated countless times the game looks fantastic despite being five years old, and the concept of Mirror's Edge itself is unique and very promising. The game sometimes rewards good intuition and reaction times in flying your way through the missions; but these moments are so few and far between that it causes the story mode to come as a bit of a disappointment. Time Trials soften the blow but do not heal it.  All in all I guess I just felt slightly let down after all the images the trailers and screenshots painted in my head, and the story itself doesn't act as a consolation by any means. If you've been dying to play this game for a long time, then go right ahead and you'll probably find it unique and interesting - but if you're browsing through games here or there and you happen to give this one a miss, it's certainly not going to be the end of the world.

Mirror's Edge is not a great game, but it has a promise of a really good series. The game is utterly unique, but by the end that wasn't enough and I was well and truely not having any fun.  There is loads of potential in the free running system, even if this first attempt fumbles. The game wants you to feel free and speedy, but there is no freedom when the path to progression is not just linear but narrow, and there is no speed when that path is not immediately obvious so you have to stop every five feet and look around for the specific ledge or rail the game had in mind for you next. Is this a game about zooming around the city, scaling walls and dashing between roof tops feeling the wind in your hair? Or is it a slow paced puzzle platformer? Because you need to decide, DICE.  In a lot of free running games, it feels too automated, because you just hold down a button and run and everything happens for you, so I like that this game puts the responsibility on your shoulders to catch this ledge, stick that landing, etc. But I think the pace could be held up better if you could basically get where you needed to go any which way you jumped, climbed or ran. That way the challenge wouldn't be 'find the ONE path forward the game has layed out for you' but rather 'you can get to your destination via any path you make for yourself, but can you do it efficiantly?'  Also the combat. I don't even need to qualify this. Nobody, not even the hardcore fans will argue that the combat isn't absolutely dreadful.  The whole thing clearly had serious budget constraints. The characters, the plot, the cutscenes, the world building, the playtime, even the mechanics, it all feels a bit bare bones. I like the characters, but I can't get invested in the concept of the Runners, because A) We're never shown why the government is apparently so evil, we just sort of have to take the protagonist's word for it while the city actually looks like a very nice and well run place, and B) It's never explained what the Runners actually... do. It's less like a complete game, and more like a pitch for a theoretically better game. But would I say yes to that pitch? Definately. The concept is loaded with potential. It just needs crap loads more tweaking. Hear's hoping Mirror's Edge 2 isn't just a love letter to Mirror's Edge 1 and actually takes the time to build upon what is basically a proof of [a very good] concept. Because with a fatter budget, and more open and flowing path to progression and combat that doesn't completely hault the all important flow, Mirror's Edge 2 could be really really cool. [2016 edit: it wasn't...]
